item.title: On Anniversary of Hurricane Maria, Storm Leaves Puerto Rico in the Dark
item.description: Hurricane Fiona reminded residents that the agonizingly slow work of giving the island a stable power grid remained unfinished.
item.dc:creator: Laura N. Pérez Sánchez, Patricia Mazzei and Erika P. Rodriguez
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodríguez For The New York Times

item.title: Three Reasons for Puerto Rico’s Power Outage
item.description: Hurricane Fiona’s devastation partly reflects several factors that preceded the storm.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Ricardo Arduengo/Reuters
item.media:description: Darkness in Guayanilla, Puerto Rico, after Hurricane Fiona made landfall on Sunday. More than a million people were still without power on Monday.

item.title: Hurricane Fiona Becomes a Major Storm in the Caribbean
item.description: Fiona strengthened to a Category 3 storm as it neared Turks and Caicos early Tuesday. It had knocked out power to most of Puerto Rico and brought heavy rain to the Dominican Republic.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodríguez For The New York Times

item.title: Strike Near Another Ukrainian Nuclear Plant Escalates Fears of Disaster
item.description: A powerful Russian missile hit 300 yards from the plant far from the front lines, Ukraine said, a reminder that despite its recent retreat, Russia can still threaten nuclear sites.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Olga Yakimovich/Reuters
item.media:description: The South Ukraine Nuclear Power Plant in Yuzhnoukrainsk, Ukraine, about 70 miles north of the city of Mykolaiv, in 2015.

item.title: In Ukraine, Glass Is a Precious Substance as Winter Looms
item.description: Russian bombs. Soaring energy costs. Severed trade links. It’s getting hard to fix all the shattered windows in Ukraine, and winter is coming.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workmen installed new windows on the eighth floor of an apartment complex that was damaged by Russian bombings in the northern city of Chernihiv.

item.title: In One Corner of Kosovo, Cheers Still Ring Out for Putin
item.description: Many ethnic Serbs, nursing grievances against NATO for a 1999 bombing campaign that broke Serbia’s grip on the territory, see President Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia as a potential savior.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Armend Nimani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Statues in Mitrovica honor Prince Lazar, left, a Christian Serb ruler at the Battle of Kosovo in 1389 and Grigory Scherbina, right, a Russian envoy to the region.

item.title: Judge Vacates Adnan Syed’s Murder Conviction, Subject of ‘Serial’ Podcast
item.description: Mr. Syed, 41, had been serving a life sentence for the 1999 murder of his high school classmate Hae Min Lee. The judge gave prosecutors 30 days to proceed with a new trial or drop the case.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Ting Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adnan Syed walks out of the Baltimore City Circuit court after a judge overturned his conviction after 23 years.

item.title: Adnan Syed’s Legal Journey: a Timeline
item.description: The defendant, who was the subject of the 2014 podcast “Serial,” had been serving a life sentence for the 1999 murder of his high school classmate Hae Min Lee.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Ting Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adnan Syed walks out of the Baltimore City Circuit court after a judge overturned his conviction after 23 years.

item.title: Videos Show Trump Allies Handling Georgia Voting Equipment
item.description: The footage raises new questions about efforts by Trump affiliates in a number of swing states to gain access to and copy sensitive voting software after the 2020 election.
item.dc:creator: Danny Hakim, Richard Fausset and Nick Corasaniti

item.title: Trump Was Warned Late Last Year of Potential Legal Peril Over Documents
item.description: A former White House lawyer sought to impress on him the need to return material he had taken with him upon leaving office.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/Getty Images
item.media:description: Eric Herschmann, center, warned former President Donald J. Trump late last year of legal liability if he did not return government materials he had taken when he left office.

item.title: Texas Sheriff to Investigate Migrant Flights to Martha’s Vineyard
item.description: The sheriff of Bexar County, Texas, said it was clear that many of the 48 migrants flown to Massachusetts had been misled and lured away to score political points.
item.dc:creator: Edgar Sandoval and Eliza Fawcett
item.media:credit: Sam Owens/The San Antonio Express-News via AP
item.media:description: “They had a right not to be preyed on and played for a fool,” Sheriff Javier Salazar of Bexar County said.

item.title: DeSantis’s Migrant Flights Aim to Jolt Midterms, and Lay Groundwork for 2024
item.description: The Florida governor’s move sending migrants to Martha’s Vineyard from Texas brought liberals’ condemnation, and more such flights may follow.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Michael C. Bender
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: “This border is now an issue in these elections,” Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida said on Sunday at an event in Green Bay, Wis.

item.title: Arrests at Southwestern Border Exceed 2 Million in a Year for the First Time
item.description: The historic pace of undocumented immigrants entering the country continued as the Biden administration tried to steer clear of immigration issues with the midterm elections approaching.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of undocumented migrants from Mexico and Guatemala being processed and detained by the Border Patrol in Sierra Vista, Ariz., in July.

item.title: Thousands Pay Tribute as Britain Says Final Farewell to Queen Elizabeth
item.description: More than 100 world leaders, including President Biden, attended the funeral for Queen Elizabeth II, and Britons lined the streets for a procession that took her to her final resting place at Windsor Castle.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

item.title: From Coronation to Funeral: Bookends to the Life of a Queen, and a Generation
item.description: For 70 years, Elizabeth II was the anchor of a nation’s identity. Charles III now will take on, or recast, that role.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: PA Images, via Getty Images; Pool photo by Frank Augstein
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth’s coronation in 1953, and her funeral on Monday.

item.title: At Queen Elizabeth’s Funeral, the Choreography of Public Mourning
item.description: The events around Queen Elizabeth’s death have unfolded with an astonishing amount of formal, choreographed movement.
item.dc:creator: Roslyn Sulcas
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Jeff J Mitchell/Pool via REUTERS
item.media:description: Pallbearers carrying Queen Elizabeth’s coffin into St. George’s Chapel in Windsor.

item.title: Biden Says the Pandemic Is Over. But at Least 400 People Are Dying Daily.
item.description: The president made the remark in an interview that aired on CBS’s “60 Minutes” on Sunday night. By Monday, the backlash was in full swing.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images
item.media:description: Covid-19 patients being treated at Providence St. Mary Medical Center in Apple Valley, Calif.

item.title: Law Enforcement Funding Package Splits Democrats Ahead of Midterm Elections
item.description: A measure to provide more money for local police departments has become mired in a long-running debate among Democrats about the politics of crime, as Republicans step up attacks.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Stephanie Lai
item.media:credit: David Dee Delgado/Reuters
item.media:description: Police officers confronting demonstrators in Grand Rapids, Mich., in April. Legislation to increase funding for local police departments has stalled on Capitol Hill.

item.title: Milly Alcock and Emily Carey Say Goodbye to ‘House of the Dragon’
item.description: In a joint interview, Milly Alcock and Emily Carey discussed their now-completed stint in the HBO epic. “We were forced to hang on to each other for dear life,” Alcock said.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:credit: Kalpesh Lathigra for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We’re very lucky in that we get along in real life, so the chemistry came very organically,” Carey said.

item.title: Don’t Let Republicans Off the Hook on Same-Sex Marriage
item.description: Democrats are letting the G.O.P. off easily by postponing a vote until after the midterms.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Michael Reynolds/EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: Sweden’s Far Right Is Rising
item.description: The idea of Sweden as a land of equal opportunity, safe from the plagues of extreme left or extreme right that haunt other countries, is gone.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Asbrink
item.media:credit: Jonathan Nackstrand/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Supporters of the Sweden Democrats political party during its election night rally.

item.title: What I Saw as the Country’s First National Climate Adviser
item.description: The private sector now sees climate as an opportunity for job creation and economic revitalization.
item.dc:creator: Gina McCarthy
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gina McCarthy

item.title: Our Predecessors Built a World of Winners and Losers. It’s Time for Something Different.
item.description: As the world transitions to recovery from the pandemic, the inequities are only widening, both between and within countries.
item.dc:creator: Darren Walker
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest last year about making the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine more accessible to poor countries.

item.title: You Cannot Be Too Cynical About Trump (or His Imitators)
item.description: The former president has company in the nether regions.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Matt Cosby for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers and migrants in Edgartown, Mass.

item.title: What Joe Biden Knows That No One Expected Him To
item.description: A liberalism that is as ambitious about solving problems through invention as it is through redistribution would be powerful indeed.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.category: Advanced Research Projects Agency for Health
item.media:credit: Illustration by Frank Augugliaro/The New York Times; photograph by EyeEm/Getty Images

item.title: At Summer’s End, a Moment of Wild Surprise
item.description: As equinox nears, the lovely cycle life is happening just behind the place in my garden where the goldenrod and the asters look so beautiful together.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl
item.media:credit: Amanda Greene

item.title: Math Is the Great Secret
item.description: If human beings invented numbers and counting, then how is it that there are numbers such as primes that have attributes no one gave them?
item.dc:creator: Alec Wilkinson
item.media:credit: María Medem

item.title: NYC Pizza Guide: the Best Clam Pie, Brooklyn Openings and More
item.description: The most important pizza goings-on across New York City.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson

item.title: The Future of San Francisco’s Fog and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
item.description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
item.media:credit: Nina Riggio for The New York Times

item.title: Vegetarian Recipes for Cozy Days
item.description: Soups, stews and comforting, feel-good foods for after a storm.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: David Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.

item.title: Do You Know Someone Who Has Died of Covid Recently? We Want to Hear From You.
item.description: New York Times reporters are looking for people who will share the stories and experiences of loved ones who have recently died.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Isadora Kosofsky for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rose River Memorial in Los Angeles, created in 2021 by the artist Marcos Lutyens, honored lives taken by Covid.

item.title: Protests Erupt in Iranian Cities After Woman’s Death in Custody
item.description: The 22-year-old’s death sparked outrage across social, religious and political factions. Four people were reported to have been killed by the security forces.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: A protest in downtown Tehran on Monday.

item.title: Physics Body Concedes Mistakes in Study of Missile Defense
item.description: Two scientists said the American Physical Society had erred in evaluating their plan to use drones to shoot down North Korean long-range missiles.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: KCNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An image released by North Korea’s state-run Korean Central News Agency showed the test launch of an intercontinental ballistic missile.

item.title: Pentagon Orders Review of Its Overseas Social Media Campaigns
item.description: The move comes after Twitter and Facebook shut down misleading accounts that they determined were sending messages to promote U.S. foreign policy.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pentagon has ordered a review of secretive operations to influence populations overseas after White House officials expressed concerns.

item.title: This Acrobatic Hunting Trick Is Straight Out of the Spider-Verse
item.description: A small Australian spider uses a Cirque du Soleil-worthy tactic to prey on fierce ants.
item.dc:creator: Sam Jones
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

item.title: What is E.M.D.R.? Understanding the Trauma Therapy Practice
item.description: The once-experimental trauma treatment has become increasingly popular. Here’s how the therapy works.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Sophie Park
item.category: The Body Keeps the Score: Brain, Mind and Body in the Healing of Trauma (Book)
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times

item.title: How to Ease and Avoid Seasonal Affective Disorder
item.description: As the days get shorter and the nights start earlier, take these steps to help prevent seasonal affective disorder.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Sergiy Maidukov

item.title: Vitamin B6 Health Benefits: Can It Reduce Depression Symptoms?
item.description: Here’s what we know about this essential vitamin’s effects on well-being.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: When to Take a Mental Health Day
item.description: Here’s how to protect your mental health in a culture that values work over well-being.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: I Gave Birth, but My Husband Developed Postpartum Depression
item.description: Many men struggle with mental health after becoming fathers. But stigma and societal norms keep them from getting help.
item.dc:creator: Kim Hooper
item.media:credit: Keith Negley

item.title: Jenny Xie Explores the Subversive Power of the Concealed and the Overlooked
item.description: In her new poetry collection, “The Rupture Tense,” Xie peeks at the past — her family’s, and China’s — to examine the consequences of “how we see, what we see, and also what we allow to remain unseen.”
item.dc:creator: Han Zhang
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: “A lot of things remained hidden by people who became accustomed to living inside these dead silences,” Xie said.

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
